page.title: 05LITTLE HADHAM CHURCH
page.content: The small church of St Cecilia is situated halfway between Hadham Hall and Little Hadham which lies in the valley of the River Ash. Between 1276 and 1870 the village church was a 'chapel' under the larger Much Hadham parish.Today Little Hadham shares its vicar with Albury, a village 2 miles to the north. Much of St Cecilia's dates from late Medieval times; restored from 1883 onwards. Flintstone is the main building material used, and the tower, containing 5 bells, is capped by a small lead spire. Most noticable internal features are a 1633 '3 decker'pulpit, 2 brasses of the arms of a Bishop of London, and a wood screen, partly 16th century About 24 Capels of Hadham Hall were buried in the vault under the altar.
